keyTakeAways: Nicholas Rossi, a 38-year-old man from Rhode Island, is serving a prison sentence of five years to life for two rape convictions in Utah, stemming from crimes committed in 2008.
Rossi faked his death in 2020 by claiming he died of non-Hodgkin lymphoma, which led to a false obituary, and used multiple aliases to evade justice.
He was identified via a decade-old DNA rape kit and arrested in Scotland in 2023 after hospital staff recognized his tattoos from an Interpol notice.
The victim in the first case described being manipulated financially and abused after dating Rossi, who later raped her in his bedroom.

Rossi had a history of fleeing the country and using false identities, including claiming to be an Irish orphan named Arthur Knight, and was previously wanted in Rhode Island for failing to register as a sex offender.
He is also accused of fraud in Ohio, and investigators believe he used at least a dozen aliases to evade capture over the years.
Utah law allows sentencing ranges, and in this case, the range for first-degree rape is five years to life; the judge sentenced him to the full range.
The case highlights the importance of addressing rape kit backlogs and the dangers of serial abusers evading accountability by faking their deaths or using false identities.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A Utah judge sentenced Nicholas Rossi, a 38-year-old man from Rhode Island, to a prison term ranging from five years to life for two rape convictions from 2008, after authorities identified him through a decade-old DNA rape kit. Rossi had falsely claimed to have died in 2020, using a fake obituary, and had previously fled the U.S. by using false identities, including claiming to be an Irish orphan named Arthur Knight. He was arrested in Scotland in 2023 due to recognition of his tattoos from an Interpol notice, extradited to Utah in January 2024, and convicted in both cases. The victims described being manipulated financially and subjected to abuse, with one stating the case was about safety and accountability. Rossi, who had a history of evading justice and failing to register as a sex offender, is now facing multiple legal consequences, including fraud charges in Ohio. The case underscores the dangers of serial abusers and the importance of clearing rape kit backlogs and using international cooperation to bring fugitives to justice.
title: Man accused of faking his own death and fleeing the US after rape charges gets at least five years in prison
